author: Primrose Riordan
title: Foreign buyers' probe nets 500 properties worth $1b
text:
Treasurer Joe Hockey forced the sale of the $39 million Point Piper home, Villa Del Mare, in Sydney's eastern suburbs. by Primrose Riordan The crackdown on foreigners illegally buying residential real estate has more than doubled to over 500 investigations and $1 billion worth of property.
Treasurer Joe Hockey said the investigations, prompted by community dob-ins, have already resulted in the forced sale of properties held by people from Singapore, Indonesia, the United Kingdom and China.
"The lowest value purchase price was $265,000, the highest $8.1 million. They have 12 months to sell the properties under the amnesty that we have provided until the ends of November," Mr Hockey said.
"So we are getting on with the job of enforcing the laws. There has been no enforcement and no successful order for at least the last 20 years. But we have taken this decision to ensure that there is integrity in the foreign investment regime and that those people who unlawfully hold Australian residential real estate are caught."
The Tax Office, which is in charge of enforcing the laws, said in June that it had 195 investigations underway .
Multinational tax crackdown The treasurer also announced legislation to tighten the tax laws to stop multinationals illegally shifting profits offshore. The measures are expected to raise hundreds of millions of dollars in extra revenue.
"The laws will apply to over 1,000 multinationals operating in Australia that have a global turnover of more than a billion dollars," Mr Hockey said.
 "I understand a number of multinationals have already come forward to identify profits previously unseen in relation to their activities in Australia. And are prepared to restructure their businesses to pay their fair share of tax in Australia."
